Article.ArticleTitle: Influence of Mn valence state and characteristic of TiO<sub>2</sub> on the performance of Mn-Ti catalysts in ozone decomposition.

AbstractText: The effects of physicochemical properties of Mn-Ti catalysts on O<sub>3</sub> conversion were examined. The catalysts were prepared by a wet impregnation method that gave manganese supported on various commercial sources of TiO<sub>2</sub>. The properties of the catalysts were studied using physicochemical techniques, including Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H<sub>2</sub> temperature-programmed reduction (H<sub>2</sub>-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). The O<sub>3</sub> decomposition tests of Mn-Ti catalysts with various manganese loadings revealed that the 10 wt% manganese catalyst exhibited optimal, excellent activity. The O<sub>3</sub> conversion and Mn valence state of the Mn-Ti catalysts were different, depending on the structure of the TiO<sub>2</sub> source. Increasing the O/Ti surface atomic ratio in TiO<sub>2</sub> increased the Mn<sup>3+</sup> ratio. The Mn<sup>3+</sup> ratio directly affected the O<sub>3</sub> decomposition activity of the Mn-Ti catalyst. When the Mn<sup>3+</sup> ratio was the largest, the catalyst showed the highest activity in O<sub>3</sub> decomposition. The valence state of Mn exposed to the surface was a critical factor in O<sub>3</sub> decomposition by Mn-Ti catalysts.
